Paragraph: The purpose of this study is to investigate the electrochemical properties of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo                        x                      high-entropy alloys in three aqueous environments which simulate acidic, marine, and basic environments at ambient temperature (∼25°C). The potentiodynamic polarisation curves of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo                        x                      alloys, obtained in aqueous solutions of H2SO4 and NaOH, clearly revealed that the corrosion resistance of the Mo-free alloy was superior to that of the Mo-containing alloys. On the other hand, the lack of hysteresis in cyclic polarisation tests and SEM micrographs confirmed that the Mo-containing alloys are not susceptible to pitting corrosion in NaCl solution.

In the past, the development of conventional alloy systems has been based primarily on one principal element, such as iron-, aluminium-, magnesium-, and nickel-based alloys, limiting the number of applicable alloy systems, even though a substantial amount of other elements is incorporated for property/processing enhancement[1,2]. In the 1990s, Inoue et al.[3]obtained the highly glass forming alloy by using at least three different elements with significantly different atomic radii. In addition, Greer[4]came up with the “confusion principle” in which he stated that the possibility of crystallisation could be lowered if the number of alloying elements was large. In the last two decades, a wide range of multicomponent amorphous alloys, including titanium-, nickel-, zirconium-, iron-, cobalt-, and copper-based alloy[5–10]systems have been developed. Multiple studies have been widely investigated the corrosion and passivation behaviour of these multicomponent amorphous alloys in a variety of electrolytes[11–34]. However, the design concept of afore-mentioned multicomponent amorphous alloys was, once again, based on one principal element. In an attempt to break through the cognitive realm of alloy design, a new multicomponent amorphous alloy system was subsequently developed[35–39]. This new alloy system is also called “high-entropy alloys” which are composed of multiprincipal elements in equimolar or near-equimolar ratios. Each element in the alloy system is no more than 35 atomic percent (atom%). This study focuses on a new alloy design with multiprincipal elements in nonequimolar ratios.

Solid solutions with multiprincipal elements tend to be more stable because they have larger mixing entropies. Following Boltzmann’s hypothesis of the relationship between entropy and system complexity, the configurational entropy change per mole, ΔSconf, during the formation of a solid solution from six elements with equimolar fractions may be calculated from the following equation:(1)ΔSconf=-klnω=-R∑i=16xilnxi=Rln6≈1.79R,xi=16wherekis the Boltzmann’s constant,ωis the number of ways of mixing, andRis the gas constant, 8.314J/mol/K. For instance, ΔSconfof equimolar alloys with 3, 5, 7, and 9 elements are 1.10R, 1.61R, 1.95R, and 2.20R, respectively. In fact, when other positive vibrational, electronic, and magnetic contributions are considered, the entropy change associated with mixing in equimolar high-entropy alloy is greater than the calculated one[40]. Under the effects of high mixing entropies and the accompanied sluggish cooperative diffusion, they easily yield the formation of simple solid-solution phases and nanostructures during solidification, rather than many binary and ternary intermetallic compounds or other complicated phases[4,40]. The simplification of their structures avoids the disadvantages of difficulty in microstructure analyses and the inherent brittleness of ordered compounds.

According to previous studies[35–39,41–45], these high-entropy alloy systems possess the following specialties: (1) ease of amorphisation and nanoprecipitation in the alloy, (2) thermal stability, (3) high hardness [Vickers hardness (HV)=700], (4) superior corrosion resistance, (5) excellent resistance to anneal softening, wear [1.2–1.8m/mm3] and oxidation. Additionally, coating technology was further expanding their range of application, to include the hard-facing of golf heads and rollers[46], diffusion barrier[47], and soft magnetic films[48]. Among those previous studies, Reference 45 pointed out that Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxwith various Mo contents (xvalues in the molar ratio,x=0–1.0) is ductile, work hardenable, and strong at high temperature up to 800°C, indicating that this alloy has potential application in high-temperature structures and working tools. However, the corrosion characteristics of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys are relatively unknown. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to investigate the electrochemical behaviour of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys under different environmental conditions.

Elements cobalt (Co), chromium (Cr), titanium (Ti), iron (Fe), and nickel (Ni) with purities of over 99wt.% were present as granules as raw materials. The 39.5wt.% Fe–60.5wt.% Mo master alloy was used with the added molybdenum (Mo). This high-entropy alloy is a six-component alloy in the form of Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox, with 1.5mol of Co, Ni, 0.5mol of Ti, and 1mol of the other two alloying elements and between zero and 1mol of the added Mo. Table 1 presents the chemical compositions of the alloys in weight percent (wt.%). The multiprincipal-element Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloy system with various Mo contents withxfrom 0 to 1.0 was prepared in this work. An induction furnace was used to melt the high-entropy alloys at 1600°C after purging with argon. First, raw materials of Co, Fe, and Ni were placed in the crucible. When Co, Fe, and Ni had melted in liquid state, then Ti, Cr, and FeMo were added to the crucible in order according to their melting points. Finally, the melt was poured into a shell mold preheated at 1100°C. The size of the ingots was 8×7×14 (cm). The high-entropy alloy cylinder for electrochemical measurements was obtained by cutting the bulk material by electric arc line into pieces that were 3mm thick and 8mm in diameter. Each test specimen was then cold mounted, using an epoxy resin to give an exposed surface area of 0.5cm2for the high-entropy alloys. Before each electrochemical experiment, all specimens were mechanically ground using a series of 240–600 silicon carbide (SiC) grit papers and cleaned with acetone and distilled water.

The microstructure and composition analyses of the as-cast alloys were carried out by JEOL 5410 scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS). X-ray diffraction (XRD) using CuKα radiation was used to identify crystalline phases and obtain the lattice parameters of these alloys. The XRD investigation was performed with the diffraction angle (2θ) from 20° to 100° at a speed of 4°/min.

The corrosion resistance of Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys was conducted in three different environmental conditions; 1molar concentration (M) sodium hydroxide (NaOH), 0.5M sulfuric acid (H2SO4), and 1M sodium chloride (NaCl), which will be referred to as base, acid, and salt solution, respectively henceforth at 25°C under atmospheric pressure. The test solution was deaerated by bubbling purified nitrogen gas before and throughout the electrochemical tests to eliminate the effect of dissolved oxygen. The electrochemical polarisation was performed in a typical three electrode cell that consisted of a specimen as the working electrode, a silver/silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) in 3M potassium chloride (KCl) as the reference electrode, and a platinum (Pt) sheet as the counter electrode. The Ag/AgCl scale (3M KCl) is 0.208V lower than the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)[49]:(2)E,VAg/AgCl+0.208=E,VSHEUnless otherwise stated in this paper, all potentials recorded were referred to standard hydrogen electrode.

Potentiodynamic polarisation measurements were made at a scan rate of 1mV/s from an initial potential of −0.5V to a final potential of 1.5V versus the open current potential (OCP). The potential was controlled and the current was measured using a potentiostat (Autolab PGSTAT30). A cyclic polarisation technique started at −0.5V by scanning at 1mV/s towards more positive potentials up to 1.5V versus the OCP, at which value the potential scan was reversed and returned to where the polarisation began. Before either of these tests was conducted, the OCP was recorded for 15min to yield a steady-state potential. Then, the specimen was cathodically polarised to a potential of −192mVSHEfor 5min to reduce the existing surface films. Following electrochemical testing, multiple electrochemical parameters were determined:Ecorr, corrosion potential, i.e., the potential where zero current density[21];Epp, primary passivation potential, the potential at which the maximum anodic current density reached in the active region[50];Esp, secondary passivation potential, the potential at which the maximum anodic current density reached in the passive region[51];Eb, the potential at which the current density suddenly increases is determined to be the breakdown potential[20]; ΔE, the difference betweenEbandEppis the estimated passive region width[42];Eprot, the protection potential where the forward and reverse scan crosses in the passive region[51];Erp, the repassivation potential is considered to be the potential at which the cyclic polarisation curves are approximately horizontal on the potential reverse scan[42];icri, critical current density, the maximum anodic current density in the active region[50];ipass, anodic current density values remain completely constant in the passive range[50]; the corrosion current density,icorr, is obtained from the curves using the intersection of the cathodic linear extrapolation (approximately −50 to −100mV from the corrosion potential) and the corrosion potential horizontal line.

Following the polarisation experiment, the specimen was cleaned using distilled water and then dried in nitrogen. Immediately thereafter, the morphology and chemical composition of the corroded surface of the high-entropy alloy was investigated using a JEOL 5410 SEM.

Section Title: Results and discussion.Microstructure of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys
Paragraph: Fig. 1 illustrates the XRD patterns of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.8) alloys. In this study, all these alloys basically belong to a simple FCC solid-solution structure. However, as Mo content in Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys increases up to 0.5 and 0.8mol, the small peaks slightly on the left and right of the matrix FCC in XRD patterns are identified as Cr and Mo rich sigma (σ) phase. As the Mo content decreases in these alloys, the peak intensities also change due to the lattice distortion caused by the different atomic size and still remains in FCC structure[45]. There is also no tendency to form complex or multiple phases when increasing the number of constituent elements. Because the wavelength of X-ray is constant (λ=1.54Å), from the angle (θ) and plane (hkl) of each diffraction peak, a set of lattice parameter can be calculated by Bragg’s law. These values of lattice parameter were plotted against cos2θ, and the precise parameter of alloy (a0) can be estimated by least squares and extrapolation method[52]. The lattice parameters of Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.8) alloys in this study are about 3.59Å. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys, which are composed of dendrites and interdentrites. According to the EDS analyses as listed in Table 2 , the interdendrite (lighter phase) of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1) alloy is Ni and Ti rich phase, and dendrite (darker phase) is Fe and Cr rich phase. Table 3 lists chemical mixing enthalpy (ΔHchem) of a pair of atoms[53–55]. As can be seen in Table 3 , Ni and Ti have the larger negative enthalpy in the alloy. Thus, they are likely to aggregated in the interdendrite phase. When increasing the Mo content in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0.5, 0.8) alloys, the interdendrites are rich in Cr and Mo, while the dendrites are rich in Co and Ni.

Section Title: Results and discussion.Microstructure of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys
Paragraph: As listed in Table 3 , Mo element has weaker binding force to other constituent elements than Fe, Co, Ni, Ti, and Cr. However, the chemical analysis of that “interdendrites” is presented in Fig. 2 c, d and Table 2 , displaying Cr and Mo richσphase, as compared to the whole Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0.5, 0.8) alloys composition ( Table 1 ). The tendency toσphase formation of an austenitic stainless steel can be known from the equivalent chromium content (ECC) equation[56]:(3)ECC=%chromium(Cr)+0.31%manganese(Mn)+1.76%molybdenum(Mo)+0.97%tungsten(W)+2.02%vanadium(V)+1.58%silicon(Si)+2.44%titanium(Ti)+1.7%niobium(Nb)+1.22%tantalum(Ta)-0.266%nickel(Ni)-0.177%cobalt(Co)

Section Title: Results and discussion.Microstructure of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys
Paragraph: If the ECC is greater than 17–18%, the steel is susceptible toσphase formation. In this case, according to the ECC equation mentioned above, the ECC values for the Co1.5CrFeNi0.5Ti0.5Mo0.5and Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8alloys were 43.73% and 53.63%, respectively. This indicates that an ECC of above 43% is susceptible to form that phase. Moreover, according to Conejero et al.[57], the Cr and Mo richσphase forms mainly at grain boundaries in 316L type stainless steels and full austenitic alloys during the solidification.

Fig. 3 plots the potentiodynamic polarisation curves of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys with various Mo contents (x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) in 0.5M H2SO4solution. The potentiodynamic polarisation curve exhibited active–passive corrosion behaviour, and the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys yielded a wide passive region (Eb−Epp=ΔE>1100mV), which indicated a tendency of the alloys to passivate. Moreover, the passive region of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy was broader than that of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.1, Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.5, and Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8alloys. TheEspoccurred for the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8alloy under 0.5M H2SO4solution, which may be attributed to the formation and dissolution of the molybdenum oxide film. Table 4 presents the electrochemical parameters of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) in deaerated 0.5M H2SO4solution. The corrosion potential (Ecorr) of the Mo-containing alloys was more apparently more noble than that of the Mo-free alloy. However, the corrosion current densities (icorr) of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.1, Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.5, and Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8alloys were 78, 72, and 69 μA/cm2, respectively; theicorrvalue dropped to 30μA/cm2when Mo was eliminated from the alloy, as in Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.Furthermore, the passive current was increased in those alloys with Mo content. The primary passivation potential (Epp) of the Mo-free alloy was lower than that of the Mo-containing alloys. The critical current density (icri) of the Mo-free alloy was a little higher than that of the Mo-containing alloys. Hence, the Mo alloying element addition has negative effect on the corrosion resistance of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys.

The broadest passive region and lowest passive current density under 0.5M H2SO4solution ( Table 4 ) were registered in the Mo-free alloy whose main characteristic is the highest presence of Cr[58]. Although the highest Mo content of Co1.5CrFeNi0.5Ti1.5Mo0.8alloy, lower Cr content with respect to Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy, generated a higher passive current density along the passive region. In the passive region, the measured current comes from the dissolution of the oxide film. The dissolution current of the oxide film increases as the Cr content in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys decreases, indicating that the addition of Cr can improve the stability of the oxide film. The increase in passive current density with decreasing Cr content is ether due to a change in structure or a decrease in thickness of the passive film. It is generally accepted that low solubility and high stability of chromic oxide (Cr2O3) based products reduce the passive current density and increase the size of the passive region on the pH-potential diagram[59].

The addition of Mo is widely recognised for its beneficial effect on the corrosion resistance of the stainless steels and has been studied extensively in the literature[60–65]. Sugimoto and Sawada[60]concluded that Mo addition to austenitic stainless steels allows formation of a passive film consisted of a Cr (III) oxyhydroxide containing Mo6+ions, which reduces the corrosion current density in the active region for acidic solution. However, Hashimoto et al.[61]proposed that the main effect of Mo was to decrease the rate of dissolution in active zones by formation and retention of Mo (VI) oxyhydroxide or molybdate (MoO42-) at these sites. Furthermore, Ogawa et al.[62]suggested that Mo is first dissolved from the substrate into the solution and then oxidised toMoO42-.

As mentioned above, many authors conclude that molybdenum species, present in the passive layer, are mainly ionic compounds (MoO42-), which are adsorbed on the top of the material surface, acting as a barrier against the electrochemical attack[63–67]. However, given the 0.5M H2SO4acidic conditions (pH<1) in this study and according to Pourbaix diagrams[68], an influence of Mo viaMoO42-formation should be considered improbable, since, in these conditions,MoO42-is unstable thermodynamically and tends to precipitate as Mo (VI) oxide, e.g., MoO3. Hence, these diagrams establish MoO3as the only compound formed in 0.5M H2SO4.

The obtained polarisation results ( Table 4 ) have revealed that Mo addition tends to increase the corrosion current density of Mo-containing alloys in 0.5M H2SO4. These results are in disagreement with Hashimoto[69]who reported that in the active region of stainless steels, where preferential dissolution of iron and chromium occurred, the formation of the passive molybdenum oxide film was responsible for a large decrease of the current density. The opposite results were found by Bojinov et al.[70]in studies of the electrochemical behaviour of anodic films on pure Cr, Fe–Cr alloys and Fe–Cr–Mo alloys in 1M H2SO4solution. The corrosion current density in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.1alloy is lower than that in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy, which may be attributed to the simultaneous presence of lower Cr and slightly higher Mo content (1.8 atom%) in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.1alloy ( Table 2 ). As the Mo content increases from 0.5 to 0.8mol in the high-entropy alloys, the interdendrite phase of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys is a Cr and Mo richσphase, and the dendrite is a Cr and Mo depleted phase. Theσphase is probably the most studied and undesirable phase in a stainless steel. Formation ofσphase can occur in the austenitic, ferritic, and duplex stainless steels. Especially in duplex stainless steels, the formation ofσphase is accelerated by increased amount of Cr and Mo[71,72]. The formation of that phase not only causes losses in ductility and toughness of the steel, but also reduces its corrosion resistance by removing Cr and Mo from the austenitic matrix[73]. Conejero et al.[57]studied premature corrosion failure of a 316L stainless steel plate exposed to a H2SO4environment. It was reported that a 316L stainless steel plate has failed due to the presence ofσphase, which is deleterious to corrosion performance of the stainless steels in H2SO4solution. Therefore, the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0.5, 0.8) alloys possessed the lower corrosion current density in comparison with the Mo-free alloy in this study, which could be also attributed to the presence ofσphase.

Fig. 4 shows the potentiodynamic polarisation curves of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys with various Mo contents (x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) in 1M NaOH solution. The correspondingEppvaried from −307 to −545mVSHEand theEspwas observed between 317 and 335mVSHEfor the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys under 1M NaOH solution. Table 5 lists the electrochemical parameters of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) in deaerated 1M NaOH solution. Theicrifor the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys increased with Mo contents, implying that the barrier to passivation increased with the increase of Mo content. Theicorrfor the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys increased with Mo contents and theEcorrvaried from −379 to −657mVSHE. Thus, adding Mo to the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys reduces the corrosion resistance under 1M NaOH solution.

Stainless steels and alloys containing Cr and Mo are susceptible to transpassive dissolution, because the oxides of these elements are unstable at high anodic potentials. Cr dissolution can take place due to the oxidation of solid Cr (III) oxide to soluble Cr (VI); similarly, Mo (IV) oxide is oxidised to soluble Mo (VI). According to the Pourbaix diagrams[68], the relevant equilibria are(4)2CrO42-+10H++6e-=Cr2O3+5H2O(4′)Eo,VSHE=1.311-0.0985pH+0.0197log(CrO42-)(5)MoO42-+4H++2e-=MoO2+2H2O(5′)Eo,VSHE=0.606-0.1182pH+0.0295log(MoO42-)

It can be observed that Mo transpassivity may occur at a significant lower potential than that of Cr. The product of the transpassive region of Mo depends on the pH of test solutions. Therefore,MoO42-is formed in NaOH solutions in this study.

The Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys achieve their corrosion resistance by formation of an oxide passive layer. It has been reported that Ni, Ti, Co, and their alloys resist corrosion by NaOH solutions[74]. For Ni and its alloys, the generally accepted Ni (II) oxide passive film contributes to retard the corrosion phenomenon by diminishing the corrosion current density (icorr) although it is not the essential element to improve the passive properties of the alloys. The Ti and its alloys have good protective properties due to its compact, passive film that contains the protective titanium dioxide (TiO2), corrosion and passivation behaviour of Co and its alloys in aqueous NaOH solutions are covered by a stable passive film which consists of Co (II) oxide/hydroxide. Therefore, from Table 5 it is clear that theicorrandicrifor the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys increased with the increase of Mo contents in 1M NaOH solutions, which could also be attributed to the simultaneous presence of low Ni, Ti, and Co content in the Mo-containing alloys in comparison with the Mo-free alloy.

A cyclic polarisation technique was adopted to determine whether the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys (x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) suffered from pitting corrosion in 1M NaCl solution at approximately 25°C. The hysteresis revealed by the cyclic polarisation curve provides information on the pitting corrosion rate and how readily a passive film repairs itself. Negative hysteresis occurs when the reverse scan current density is less than that for the forward scan, and positive hysteresis occurs when the reverse scan current density exceeds the forward scan current density[75].

Cyclic polarisation measurements were made at a scanning rate of 1mV/s. The potential scan began at −0.5V and continued in the anodic direction until the potential was 1.5V versus the OCP, at which value the potential scan was reversed and returned to where the polarisation began. Fig. 5 plots the cyclic polarisation curves of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys with various Mo contents (x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8). The black and gray arrows next to the forward and reverse anodic branches indicate the potential scan directions. In terms of the electrochemical parameters shown in Table 6 , the addition of Mo moves theEbin the noble direction. The cyclic polarisation curve of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy was referred to as a pseudo-passive curve because the curve did not exhibit a distinctEpp, but theEbwas observed. The difference betweenEbandEppwas the estimated passive region width ΔE. The ΔEfor the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy was 557mV. As the Mo content in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys increased from 0.1 to 0.8mol, the ΔEvaried between 1371 and 1429mV. Therefore, the ΔEof the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys broadened due to the effect of Mo, which is in agreement with Sedriks et al.[58]. The Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys (x=0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys showed negative hysteresis in the cyclic polarisation curve, indicating that the Mo-containing alloys were resistant to pitting corrosion in 1M NaCl solution, as can be seen in Fig. 5 b–d. However, the positive hysteresis of the cyclic polarisation curve demonstrates that pitting of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy can be induced in 1M NaCl solution, as in Fig. 5(a) . The area contained within a positive hysteresis loop is related to the amount of pit propagation that occurs during the cycle, according to Wilde[76]. The intersection at the passive region defined protection potential (Eprot), below which the established pits on metal surface apparently could not keep on growing. In contrast, new pits would initiate only aboveEb. BetweenEprotandEb, new pits could not initiate, but old ones still could grow. Furthermore, theicorrof the Mo-containing alloys was lower than that of the Mo-free alloy. Therefore, adding Mo element has positive effect on the corrosion resistance of Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys in 1M NaCl solution.

It has been well established that the addition of Mo to stainless steels improves the pitting corrosion resistance in media containing chloride[50,58,77–78]. It has been considered that Mo could formMoO42-ions in the solid state in the outer regions of the film in neutral NaCl solutions according to Pourbaix diagrams[68]. ThisMoO42-layer is cation selective and can serve as a very effective pitting inhibitor, which resists the incorporation of anions such as Cl−and Br−, allowing for the growth of the Cr oxide inner barrier layer. The resulting bipolar layer stabilises the oxide phase[65].

It has been reported that the content of Cr and Mo plays an important role in the corrosion resistance of stainless steels and nickel alloys[79–81]. For Fe–Ni–Cr–Mo stainless steel, such as 316 stainless steels, the relative effectiveness of Cr and Mo contents on pitting or crevice corrosion usually can be assessed qualitatively by pitting resistance equivalent (PRE), which is represented by the empirical equation[82]:(6)PRE=%Cr+3.3%MoIn this study, according to the PRE equation mentioned above, the PRE values for the pitting-resistant Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.1, Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.5, and Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8alloys are 26.32, 59.05, and 79.31, respectively. The Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0alloy, which is susceptible to pitting corrosion, has PRE value 16.87. This indicates that a PRE of above 26 is crucial to protect the as-cast Mo-containing alloys from pitting corrosion in 1M NaCl solution.

The obtained polarisation results ( Table 6 ) have shown that the Mo-containing alloys exhibit lower corrosion current density than that of the Mo-free alloy, which is in agreement with the other authors[50,58,77–78]. However, the corrosion current density of the Mo-containing alloys decreases as the Mo content increases from 0.1 to 0.8mol. Although the PRE value for the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8is the highest among the Mo-containing alloys, the corrosion current density is the lowest among the Mo-containing alloys. The major drawbacks of the PRE equation in using parameters based on Cr and Mo contents is that they ignored the relationship between microstructure and pitting corrosion resistance. Kim et al.[83]investigated corrosion ofσphase formation of 25% Cr duplex stainless steel (DSS) in 4M NaCl solutions. According to the author, the increase of Mo content in DSS has been reported to promote formation ofσphase, leading to a reduction in pitting corrosion resistance of the DSS. Similar results were found by Cvijović and Radenković[84]in studies of the microstructure and pitting corrosion resistance of the annealed DSS in 0.5M NaCl solution. In this study, as the Mo content increases from 0.5 to 0.8mol in the high-entropy alloys, the interdendrite phase of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys is a Cr and Mo richσphase, and the dendrite is a Cr and Mo depleted phase. Mo and Cr contents are higher in the interdendrite than in the dendrite, as can be observed in Table 2 . The PRE value and the associated resistance to pitting may become notably different in the two phases. Therefore, the formation ofσphase in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0.5, and 0.8) alloys can result in a significant degradation of pitting corrosion resistance in 1M NaCl solutions.

A passive film breaks down when the applied potential is raised into the transpassive region of the potentiodynamic polarisation curve, and the formation of pits can be initiated at discrete locations on the metal surface[85]. A passive film is generally believed to repair itself when the repassivation potential (Erp) exceeds the corrosion potential. As listed in Table 6 , theErpis more noble than theEcorr, regardless of whether Mo is incorporated. As the Mo content in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys increases from 0 to 0.1mol, theErprises from 32.5 to 761mVSHE. However, as the Mo content in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys increases from 0.1 to 0.8mol, theErpfalls from 761 to 476mVSHE. It is assumed that the presence of theσphase in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mox(x=0.5, 0.8) alloys reduces the repassivation performance. Therefore, the addition of appropriate Mo to Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys improves the ability to restore its passive film.

Section Title: Results and discussion.SEM photomicrographs of corroded surfaces
Paragraph: Fig. 6 presents the SEM microstructure of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys after potentiodynamic polarisation in deaerated 0.5M H2SO4. According to the SEM images, surface examination showed that the major types of corrosion were mainly uniform corrosion. As the Mo content increases from 0.5 to 0.8mol in the high-entropy alloys, according to the Table 2 , the interdendrite phase of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys is a Cr and Mo rich phase, and the dendrite is a Cr and Mo depleted phase. The active dendrites are coupled to the Cr and Mo depleted and Cr and Mo rich passive interdendrites. The low anode/cathode surface area ratio results in galvanic corrosion at the dendrites, and the electrochemical action causes attack along the dendrites in Cr and Mo depleted alloys. To verify the composition of the interdendrite phase, the EDS analysis was used, and the result is listed in Table 7 . There are two areas, designated A and B in Fig. 6 c after the potentiodynamic polarisation of the alloy Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.5in deaerated 0.5M H2SO4. Area A is the interdendrite and area B is the dendrite. The EDS analysis demonstrates that the interdendrites of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.5alloy are rich in Cr and Mo, but poor in Co, Ni, and Fe. Especially, the atomic percent of Mo in the interdendrites (23.9 atom%) considerably exceeds that in the dendrites (6.4 atom%) in the Co1.5CrFeNi0.5Ti0.5Mo0.5alloy. Therefore, the corrosion on the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys (x=0.5, and 0.8) alloys was concentrated to the dendrites.

Section Title: Results and discussion.SEM photomicrographs of corroded surfaces
Paragraph: The SEM micrographs of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys after potentiodynamic polarisation in deaerated 1M NaCl are shown in Fig. 7 . The corroded surfaces of the Mo-free alloy showed that the major types of corrosion were mainly pitting corrosion, not uniform corrosion. It is observed that several pits formed in 1M NaCl on Mo-free alloy. Moreover, we find that there are no pits on the surface of Mo-containing alloys, supporting the previous finding that Mo-containing alloys are free of pitting corrosion in 1M NaCl solution. It appears, therefore, that the Mo-free alloy is more susceptible to pitting corrosion in 1M NaCl solution than the Mo-containing alloys. These results are in agreement with the cyclic polarisation curves as presented in Fig. 5 .

Section Title: Results and discussion.SEM photomicrographs of corroded surfaces
Paragraph: Fig. 8 a–d illustrates the SEM microstructure of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys after potentiodynamic polarisation in deaerated 1M NaOH. It is clear that the corrosion mode in NaOH is more of general type, indicating passivating nature of the alloys in this oxidising solution. The pit-like contrasts on the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys (x=0, 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys are due to the microporosities formed during the casting and the mechanical polishing effect, compared to Fig. 2 , images of the as-cast Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys with various Mo contents. The surface of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys (x=0.1, 0.5, and 0.8) alloys is roughened by general corrosion. Similar results were found by Mondal et al.[22]in the studies of the electrochemical behaviour of multicomponent amorphous and nanocrystalline zirconium (Zr)-based alloys in different environments, which demonstrated that pitting has occurred in the alloy in NaCl solutions whereas no pitting has observed in NaOH and H2SO4solutions.

The electrochemical characteristics of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxhigh-entropy alloys in solutions of 0.5M H2SO4, 1M NaCl, and NaOH have been studied in this paper. The potentiodynamic polarisation curves of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys in acidic solution exhibit active–passive corrosion behaviour, yielding an extensive passive region. The corrosion current density and passive current density of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5alloy are significantly lower than those of the Co1.5CrFeNi0.5Ti1.5Mo0.1, Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.5, and Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Mo0.8alloys. Therefore, the Mo-free alloy is more resistant to general corrosion than that of the Mo-containing alloys in acidic environments. On the other hand, the cyclic polarisation curves indicate that the Mo-free alloy tends to pitting corrosion in 1M NaCl solution accounting for the lower breakdown potential and narrower range of potentials in the passive region. Additionally, the negative hysteresis in the reverse scans of the cyclic polarisation curves and SEM images show that the Mo-containing alloys are not susceptible to pitting corrosion in deaerated 1M NaCl solution in this study, and that the passive film is generally believed to repair itself. It is revealed that the addition of Mo in the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys improves the pitting resistance in chloride environments, in that the breakdown potential for the Mo-containing alloys are much higher than that for the Mo-free alloy. Potentiodynamic polarisation curves of the Co1.5CrFeNi1.5Ti0.5Moxalloys, obtained in 1M NaOH solution, clearly reveal that the corrosion resistance decreases with the Mo content increases.
